intro: Tetraglochidium hallieri, commonly known as the New Zealand flax, is a flowering plant native to New Zealand. It belongs to the family Asparagaceae and is characterized by its strap-shaped leaves and small, inconspicuous flowers. The plant is often found in coastal and lowland areas, thriving in moist, well-drained soils. Its fibrous leaves have been traditionally used by Māori for making baskets and other woven items. The species is also valued for its ornamental qualities and ecological importance in native habitats.
